description: From the Christian ritual, which was traditionally accompanied in Catholicism by a recitation of Psalm 25:6 (Psalm 26:6, in the Hebrew and in most modern translations) which in Latin begins with the word lavābō (“I will wash”). The sense of "room with a toilet" developed under the influence of lavatory and lav.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A ritual involving the washing of one's hands at a church's offertory before handling the Eucharist.
(Christianity) The small towel used to dry the priest's hands following the ritual.
examples: These small liturgical towels got  […]  the name of Lavabo cloths or Lavaboes.

entries.meaning: A washbasin, particularly (Christianity) the one in a church used in the ritual.
(architecture) A trough used for washing at some medieval monasteries.
(humorous, euphemistic) A lavatory: a room used for urination and defecation.
